title: The Mind Robber
dialogue_triumphs: Gulliver: 'We obey our creator, that is all that can be expected of any character, unless the Master bids us otherwise.'
goofs: In episode one, as the Doctor pushes the 'white' Jamie and Zoe into the TARDIS, the words 'producer Peter Bryant' can be seen on the scanner.

continuity_notes.name: TARDIS Emergency Unit
continuity_notes.description: A device that takes the TARDIS out of the time-space dimension and out of reality.

continuity_notes.name: Master of the Land of Fiction
continuity_notes.description: A writer of pulp fiction kidnapped from England in the summer of 1926, now controlling the Land of Fiction.
continuity_notes.current_status: Controlled by a computer master brain

continuity_notes.name: The Karkus
continuity_notes.description: A Germanic superhero from strip-cartoons in the 'hourly telepress' of the year 2000.
continuity_notes.current_status: Encountered by the Doctor and companions

continuity_notes.name: Mercury Fluid Links
continuity_notes.description: A component of the TARDIS that begins to vaporize, causing issues.

technobabble: The Karkus's anti-molecular ray disintegrator gun is, according to the Doctor, 'scientifically impossible'.
roots: Peter Ling's observation of Crossroads fans who believe their favourite fictional characters are real
links: The Greatest Show in the Galaxy

locations.name: Land of Fiction
locations.description: A realm outside of reality where fictional characters and stories come to life.
locations.origin: Unknown, possibly created by the Toymaker or the Gods of Ragnarok

future_history: The Karkus is from the year 2000, suggesting the existence of an 'hourly telepress' with strip-cartoons in that time.
qv: The Gods of Ragnarok ('The Greatest Show in the Galaxy')
additional_notes: Zoe is seen wearing a lamé catsuit, noted as a 'Fashion Victim'. The story may be interpreted as a dream sequence, with the White Robots and Tin Soldiers possibly representing Jamie and Zoe's subconscious images of Cybermen and Quarks.
bottom_line: A visually astounding serial with a combination of disturbing images, superb literalism, and memorable set-pieces, making it one of the most memorable stories of the era.
